SupportingEvidence: Enrichment of hepatocyte metabolic genes (CYP2E1, BAAT, ADH1B, APOC1/APOE) consistent with differentiated fetal-like phenotype
GLUL (glutamine synthetase) indicates pericentral/WNT-activated hepatocyte identity common in fetal hepatoblastoma
Mitochondrial OXPHOS transcripts (MT-CO2, MT-CYB, MT-ATP6, MT-ND4) align with mature metabolic programs
Lack of classic embryonal/high-proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, TOP2A, CCNB1) among top genes
REG3A, HLA-B, APCS reflect liver acute-phase/immune features but are not subtype-defining
Heat-shock chaperones (HSP90AA1, HSPA1A) suggest stress response without contradicting fetal identity
SuggestedExperiments: IHC/IF for GLUL, CYP2E1, BAAT, APOE/APOC1 to confirm hepatocyte differentiation
Ki-67 and TOP2A staining to exclude embryonal high-proliferation regions
Assess WNT activation: nuclear β-catenin (CTNNB1) and AXIN2/LEF1 expression
Functional assays: urea production, bile acid conjugation (BAAT activity), CYP2E1 activity
Spatial transcriptomics or multiplex IHC to correlate with fetal histology and detect mixed areas
Genetic profiling for CTNNB1 mutations and common HB CNAs to support subtype assignment
